module.name: HTML
module.param: In the preceding examples you used the HTML module by specifying an 'html' param in the config. However, sometimes, you want to use the same content over and over again across many views. In these cases, it is better not to use HTML's "html" param, but instead use its "src" param. If you set "src" to "foo.html", then the module will look for a file at "/etc/apps/<appname>/appserver/static/foo.html".

module.name: HTML
module.param:
Notes

  1. Note that you cannot specify both the "src" and the "html" params.
  2. While you can use $$foo$$ substitution in the value of the "src" param, note that it will only substitute values that it finds in the querystring of the page URL. In other words, you cannot dynamically change which external file is loaded at runtime by varying the value of a $$foo$$ token.
  3. Read the specification for the Sideview module: HTML and its params.
